content:
That's a great approach! Starting with a lower price point will help you test the market, attract buyers, and build your portfolio. As you gain more experience and confidence, you can always adjust your prices accordingly.

Remember to also keep track of your sales, expenses, and customer feedback to refine your pricing strategy and improve your craft. And don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or need further guidance.

**Additional Tips:**

1. **Take high-quality photos**: Make sure your photos are well-lit, in focus, and showcase your artwork from different angles.
2. **Write detailed descriptions**: Include information about the artwork, such as the materials used, inspiration, and dimensions.
3. **Use relevant keywords**: Use keywords that buyers might use when searching for artwork like yours, such as "acrylic on canvas," "abstract art," or "emerging artist."
4. **Engage with potential buyers**: Respond promptly to inquiries, and be open to custom commissions or requests.

By following these tips and staying committed to your craft, you'll be well on your way to selling your artwork and building a loyal customer base.

Good luck with your online sales, and I hope you'll keep me updated on your progress!
